document_title: Pneumonia: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
8.1. Vaccination
Currently, vaccines are available to prevent some pneumonia and flu diseases. In particular, vaccines to prevent pneumonia in children are widely used. Doctors recommend other pneumonia vaccines for children under 2 years old, and children 2 to 5 years old are at particular risk for pneumococcal disease. To prevent this disease, there is PCV 10 vaccine, trade name Synflorix, which helps prevent 10 different strains of pneumococcal bacteria. For adult pneumonia, there are currently many types of Covid-19 vaccines such as: AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson's Janssen...
8.2. Increase hygiene
To protect yourself from respiratory infections that sometimes lead to pneumonia, wash your hands frequently or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer, and wear a mask. You need to rinse your mouth every day with salt water or antiseptic solution. This habit helps kill bacteria in the throat, dilute phlegm, open the airways and minimize complications due to infection.
8.3. No active or passive smoking
Cigarette smoke has the potential to damage the lungs' natural defenses against respiratory infections.
8.4. Keep the immune system strong
Ways to strengthen the immune system are: get enough sleep, exercise regularly and eat healthy.
